docs.lead_paragraph: The accounting firm Arthur Andersen lost its license to practice in Texas today, the home state of its former client Enron. The state board that regulates the Texas accounting profession voted unanimously to revoke the firm's license because of the company's obstruction of justice conviction.
docs.abstract: Arthur Andersen loses license to practice accounting in Texas because of its obstruction of justice conviction in Enron Corp's collapse; will pay $1000 fine (M)

docs.snippet: The Enron Development Corporation hopes to restart construction on its power  plant in India by May 1 after agreeing on a new price for the plant's electrical output, a company spokeswoman, Diane Bazelides, said yesterday. The company reached the ...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Enron Development Corporation hopes to restart construction on its power plant in India by May 1 after agreeing on a new price for the plant's electrical output, a company spokeswoman, Diane Bazelides, said yesterday. The company reached the revised power purchase agreement on Thursday with the Maharashtra State Electricity Board. The agreement still needs final approval, however, from the Maharashtra Cabinet, the central Government of India and project lenders. The government of Maharashtra canceled the project last August, contending it was too expensive and could damage the environment. But the state agreed to revive the project in January, after the company offered cost cuts and reductions in electricity prices. (AP)

docs.lead_paragraph: A report by the staff of a Senate panel has concluded that Robert E. Rubin ''did not act contrary to law'' in the weeks before Enron collapsed by suggesting to the under secretary of the Treasury that he urge major credit-rating agencies to delay issuing a downgrade of Enron. Mr. Rubin, who resigned as Treasury secretary in July 1999 and several months later became chairman of Citigroup's executive committee, called Peter R. Fisher, the under secretary of the Treasury, on Nov. 8, 2001, after learning that Enron was close to losing its investment-grade rating.
docs.abstract: Senate Governmental Affairs Committee report concludes former Treasury Sec Robert E Rubin 'did not act contrary to law' in weeks before Enron collapsed by suggesting to then Treasury Under Sec Peter R Fisher that he urge major credit-rating agencies to delay issuing downgrade of Enron; Rubin, who resigned as Treasury secretary in July 1999 and several months later became chairman of Citigroup's executive committee, called Fisher on Nov 8, 2001, after learning that Enron was close to losing its investment-grade rating; Citigroup stood to lose more than $1 billion that it had lent to Enron if its credit rating was downgraded and company subsequently collapsed; Rubin had been asked to make call by Michael A Carpenter, head of Citigroup's investment banking unit at time (M)
